newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: FEATURE - Bangladeshis lured by healers' ads.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Bangladeshis lured by healers' ads.

text.p: Bangladeshis with problems from obseity to premature ejaculation are being lured by a range of cures that doctors dismiss as nonsense.
"No erection? Premature ejaculation? Nothing to worry about ... we can help, with a 100 percent guarantee," a healer promises in one of hundreds of newspaper advertisements.
Many ads also guarantee fast results.
"A 70-year-old man will feel young again within days and will feel like a stallion. His wife will be more than happy..." says another.
Other advertised cures cover diseases from cancer to AIDS to whooping cough, diabetes and piles.
Treatment costs are very low and claimed success rates are high. The healers print testimonials from former patients happy with the results, along with their photographs.
One Dhaka-based firm offering a cure for obesity claims its clients can slim down to a "fine-tuned body" without any physical exercise or even without changing diet.
"Why worry? Eat, drink and be merry. Leave the rest to us," one firm's official said.
He says patients also come from abroad, especially from India, where thousands of Bangladeshis also head for treatment every month.
"Our people go to India because they are still ignorant of the tremendous power of our medicine and treatment."
Other healers appearing in the newspapers include one who can "guide your future with direction received through dreams."
Some rely on the divine power of stones.
"What do you want? I can give you wealth, a happy soul, financial prosperity, great success and the solution to any problem you may have," says healer Dewan Golam Sarwar.
Woman healer Sufia Begum promises in her advertisement in Ittefaq newspaper: "My challenge...healing or cure is available through believing only."
She says she can cure the "hardest of problems, including pains from broken love, simply by the power of meditation."
Other healers use substances extracted from snakes, water from the Holy Land, dew drops and Kastari, a rare fragrance derived from deer.
At shops called Dawakhana, practitioners of herbal medicine treat patients from all over the country, most of them unable to afford expensive care in hospitals and clinics.
The patients often undergo an initial psychological session, where they are told by the hakims (physicians) that the main healer is Allah.
"We just deliver the cures offered by our creator," one Hakim said.
"I have a cooling feeling inside me. I felt good and a little relieved too," one patient at a Dawakhana said after his psychological session.
The medicines are cheap, made from herbs and taken easily, though some have a bad taste, another patient said.
How reliable are they?
Doctors who studied advanced medical science say most of the cures are ineffective, except for some herbal medicines.

"Homoeopathy is the only reliable alternative to allopathy (orthodox medicine)," Dr Mamoon Ahmed said. "Herbal medicines sometimes work, only if the disease can be properly diagnosed. But it's not possible without advanced scientific research."
Doctors also dismissed street-side healers, who deliver lectures over megaphones, and offer money back guarantees if their medicines do not work.
"They simply cheat people," one said.
